James juggernaut rolls on

26/10/2014

James College mauled Langwith 5-1 for their third victory in succession

Image by

By undefined undefined

JAMES FIRSTS 5-1 LANGWITH FIRSTS Revolution Premier Division Good players and great teams have a habit of making difficult things look easy- a penchant for making the challenging appear merely elementary. When confronted with pressure and adversity, their sprinkling of individual talent and weight of collective organisation always somehow seem to win through. After another dominant display, we are left with no choice but to place this James College side into such a category. Langwith forced their way back into serious contention before half-time, but an inspired tactical switch and some razor-sharp attacking from quicksilver forwards James Edwards and Andrew Jopson handed James what turned out to be a convincing victory. Edwards wasted no time at all in announcing himself on the game. After shooting over, he then fed Jopson, who drifted this way and that, unleashing two of his specialities from wide without testing keeper Steve le Cornu unduly. A matter of moments later, his partner in crime Edwards showed him exactly how it is done, albeit he was indebted to some calamitous handling from le Cornu. James' skipper Mandeep Sangha punched in a testing centre and the goalkeeper completely misjudged it, allowing the ball to escape his grasp and Edwards to nod into an open goal from scarcely five yards out. Although Langwith were able to stem the tide of James' attacks until beyond the half hour mark, Matt Singleton continued to commend himself with some intelligent forward play. The tall striker held the ball up expertly and was never afraid to engage in the unattractive side of his role- running the channels consistently- and got his reward after 33 minutes. He backed in to Oliver Henn on the left byline, rolled his marker inside and toe-poked into the far corner. It was the least attractive goal of the game, but the most deserved. After going 2-0 down, Langwith embarked on their best spell of the game. Tom Benney, their only UYAFC representative, combined well with Miguel Vidal down the left hand side and drilled a disappointing drive into Balzan's body. Benney made amends with an instinctive finish five minutes later, bundling home at the back post after Bastian Koop's driven ball across the face of goal. In this period they began to integrate target man Koop into moves and to harvest the rich fruit of Jack Parsinson's ceaseless industry. At half-time, James sacrificed Edwards' stealth for Ralph Gill's brains, instructing the defender to direct traffic in a midfield area which Langwith had claimed for their own before the interval. This switch had an instant impact; Singleton failed to take advantage of a one-on-one situation, as le Cornu saved well with his feet, before Jopson headed over a highly presentable cross from Dave Clarkson. As the floodlights came on, James took command. Marcus Campbell lost the ball in midfield and Matt Singleton bounded down the right channel. The striker shifted his weight onto his left, firing at le Cornu, who parried perfectly into the path of Gill, full-stopping a lung-busting midfield burst by heading in the rebound from close range. Two minutes later, and James were 4-1 up. Ralph Gill unfurled a beauteous long-range ball, which began at shoulder height and ended at Singleton's toes with only the keeper to beat. This time, the striker successfully placed his shot into the top corner. Only a minor scuffle- when Langwith adjudged Balzan to have shoved Alex Chaimo into the stanchion- interrupted James' progress, and they proceeded to extend their lead when Joe Fox converted a penalty, awarded after Declan Tuite was brought down. James captain Mandeep Sangha was understandably satisfied: "At half-time we knew that the next goal would probably win the game, and we managed to get it. I was very happy with the second half, and we missed some chances so could have had about eight in the end. I'm delighted with our squad and, as well as a strong starting eleven, we've shown that our other players can make a difference." Langwith captain Tom Benney saw signs of encouragement: "We got right on top of them at the end of the first half, and started the second very well. The bit of fighting they started shows that we got into their heads at this stage. All in all, I was very happy with that performance and don't think that 5-1 does us justice at all." James (4-4-2): Balzan; Sangha, Gill, Elliott, McCormick; Clarkson, Jobling, Fox, Edwards; Jopson, Singleton Subs: Axford, Tuite Langwith (5-3-2): Le Cornu; Grindell, Henn, Pickersgill, Chaimo, Benney; Campbell, Parsinson, Vidal; Martin, Koop Subs: Brooks, MacDonald, Sarrafan Man of the Match: Matt Singleton
